title: Is randomness linked in any way to infinity? - Quora

response.answer_text: Thanks for A2A. There are some minor mathematical relationships, but nothing that I would consider hugely significant.  Perhaps the most interesting of these (to me) is that if you randomly select a number between 0 and 1, with equal chance for every number, the probability of selecting a rational number (fraction) is precisely 0--though that does not mean it is impossible!   [EDIT TO ADD:] This relates to infinity because not only are there infinitely many fractions in [0,1], but there are fractions "infinitely close" to every number in [0,1]. (We say that the fractions are dense in [0,1].)   I would say that the link is more psychological, as in: infinity and randomness are both mathematical constructs that most people do not understand very well, and for which human intuition generally fails.

Well, they are certainly at least linked in this question. Beyond that we might say that a random number in the interval [math](0,1)[/math] has an infinite non-repeating decimal expansion with probability one, because almost all such numbers are transcendental. But I don't think there is any profound or deep link between randomness and infinity.
